responses.content:
Explanation: The original statement "If I charge my phone, it will have power" is a conditional statement in logic, which can be represented as P → Q, where P is "I charge my phone" and Q is "it will have power." The question asks whether we can infer "If I charge my phone and it has a dead battery, it will have power," which is (P ∧ R) → Q, where R is "it has a dead battery."

In classical logic, if P → Q is true, then for any additional condition R, (P ∧ R) → Q is also true. This is because the truth of P → Q means that whenever P is true, Q must be true, regardless of other factors. Adding R to the antecedent does not negate this implication; it only strengthens the condition under which Q is expected to hold. Specifically, (P ∧ R) → Q is logically equivalent to ¬(P ∧ R) ∨ Q, and since P → Q is equivalent to ¬P ∨ Q, if ¬P ∨ Q is true, then (¬P ∨ ¬R) ∨ Q is also true, ensuring the validity of the inference.

In this case, even though "it has a dead battery" might seem relevant, the original implication does not depend on the battery's state; it only asserts that charging the phone leads to power. Therefore, the inference is logically sound.

Answer: yes
